reviewText:
Early Access Review

Just a quick review.

* great optics!
* some epic moments and places
* many movement methodes
* its about exploring, no fighting (and thats not a bad thing)
* playtime for me 3 hours. You could be faster if you want, but why would you want that in such an eviroment? And i will defenetly go back and sink some more hours.
* price 19,99 euro and wort every cent of it
* only minor issues (get stuck some time, but could teleport out of it)
* it runs really smoth with my gtx970. got no judder at all, even the big areas running great
* besides the ending of call of the starseed" thats to most epic experience at this time!
* immersion is great

negatives
* not many at all. All i could say would be nitpicking.
* you have to be aware that this is an exploration game. There is not much to do
hoursPlayed: shooting flares and look out for things that will kill you. But like i said
voteText: thats not a bad thing.\n\nIf you are into a scifi setting
helpfulPercent: buy it. And if you are not

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Now if you are considering to buy this game, consider these points

It was made by a single developer, for 2 years.

It is in early development

The developer behind this game has a large list of titles behind him such as GTA, Max Payne, Tomb Raider, Jet Moto, The Matrix, and the list goes on.

The dev could easily just add more to the game through DLC, but he has firmly stated in the podcast he (a simple google search will do) that he wants to continue to add on to this game for as long as absolutly possible without any extra cost

Music is by the musician behind Bioshock 1, 2, and 3

Multiple modes of moving and turning for the experienced VR player and the unexperienced

There are no loading screens during your gameplay experience

Think of the price of a movie ticket. Now for this you can replay it as many times as you wish, take your time and walk around the world of imagination that this game is. There are many paths you can take, you can interact with the world around you, and more areas in development.

The atmosphere is amazing, he somehow manages to capture the feel of a disney park ride, without even putting you on a track (well except for one point during the intro). Certain aspects of the game fill you with that wonder, reminds me of how I felt watching tomorrowland. Certain aspects of the unknown hidden deep in the caves of this game also prove, you can play a game not even remotly related to a horror genra with no jump scares, and still feel tense and nervous of whats around this corner.

Although I praise it a lot, of coarse this game is definitly not without flaw. There are of coarse points you might get stuck (tip: teleport mode helps you get out), and there are definitly bugs (pun not intended).  This is an early access game and nowhere near the final product. There is limited gameplay, I havn't had time to play through all of it, but from videos it seems you can generally go for a couple hours and still discover new things you may have passed before. But dont let that worry you, this is definitly a game you can constantly go back to, and is a great demo to show those unfamiliar with VR. The whole atmoshphere and music really reminds me of those old retro space games you might find in an arcade, which is nice.

Now if you are considering buying this, please do of coarse with anything you buy do some research. Watch a video and see if its worth it in your opinion, I know i hyped it up a lot, but just like any game the wonder I felt wont be shared by everyone. If you do watch videos, just dont watch too much so you can still feel suprised about whats waiting for you around the corner.

Just dont go into this expecting a game, go into it expecting a VR experience

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I just finished iOMoon in its current state as of 1st of May 2016. The sense of wonder while roaming around in the exploration pod is quite tangible. I love how it slowly ramps up the experience in both scale and sense of danger. You'll see things both unexpected and familiar - but never on a scale that would exist in the real world. It's distorted and actually a bit scary at times. It feels like travelling in a very obscure piece of art.

The music and wind audio is the one thing that bothered me a bit, as mentioned in my other post. The music itself is good. Expressive and bombastic during moments of danger and then morphs into a more subtle vibe when exploring the caves. But I miss the silence. Silence is such an underrated concept in games. Imagine total silence during the cave lake sequences. Just you, the water ripples and the sound of the entities in the cave. I would love to experience that. I also found it odd that the wind sound effect seemed constant, even in the caves. Almost like it was part of the music and not the environment.

I don't know where this experience will go from here. But from what I've seen it is certainly worthy of your time.

Played on the Oculus Rift CV1.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Reaction: Bored out of my wits
Level design: Mid 1990's
Music score: 1970's Overly Dramatic Hollywood Style
Turning speed: Infuriatingely slow, even on maximum
Turbo button: Awkward to press on a controller, doesn't last long enough
Cockpit: Obscures view (can be disabled)
Fell throught the ground: once
Hit Invisible walls: numerous
Health: Fake - Pretty sure you can't die
Oxygen supply: Fake - Pretty sure you can't suffocate
Overly concerned with: VR Comfort
Fails to deliver: Game, gameplay
3D: Gimmick
Reason for the game's existance: Make money off VR adopters before market is saturated
Worth the price: Hell no!
Will be asking for a refund: Hell yes

Summary: May be tempting to buy if you just got a VR headset, but don't bother or wait for a sale.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A fairly good and comfortable Oculus title... but it gets a down vote from me because of its relentless sensory abuse.  The music, while well produced, is absolutely everything except subtle.  It pounds you into submission without mercy or rest.

The visuals are reasonably good, and often times quite creepy.  But on the whole it felt more like a voyage through Willy Wonka's Chocolate Factory than any sciency" voyage into a possible realm...

The whole thing is rather on rails
date: making it an IO version of the Haunted Mansion at Disney except you control the speed of progress.\n\nOn my DK2 it was a bit laggy at most times."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

+ Great visuals
+ Fantastic soundtrack
+ Very immersive
+ You can choose your prefered locomotion style
+ Nice performance
+ Very polished for Early Access
+ 3-4h of gameplay (at least for me, took my time)

- Shallow gameplay, lacks interaction with the enviroment, no real objectives
- No real story
- I don't like beeing a brain in a pod. Would prefer a real body for even more immersion
- Can't upgrade Brainpod"
date: could use some crafting elements\n- Can't disable Xbox 360 force feedback
hoursPlayed: makes my hands numb and drains the batterys of my controller\n\nFor me
voteText: the game was worth it's money. If you like high immersive experiences mixed with some exploration
